utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Leonard, what time does your mom’s plane get in?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t know, some time tomorrow morning.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Don’t you want to know for sure?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No need to. As soon as she flies into California airspace, I’ll feel a disturbance in the Force.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: It’s so nice both of your moms are coming in to see you guys get an award.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, my mother’s been there for every honour I’ve won since I beat out my twin sister for the did it on the potty trophy. How does this look?

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Aw, it’s so nice. She’s gonna love it.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Sure, his mom gets roses. When I want them, they’re a bouquet of severed plant genitals.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You act like I didn’t get you that mushroom log on Valentine’s Day.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: He’s right. Roses die, but a moist rotting log will pump out mushrooms for two or three magical years.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: You know, your mom’s never been too thrilled with our relationship. Maybe I should get her something so she warms up to me.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: If you could run out and get a PhD, that might make her like you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Really? It didn’t work for you.

utterance.speaker: Amy
utterance.content: Do you think the moms will get along?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Uh, I don’t know. They’re pretty different.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Maybe they’ll be best friends. One of them is brilliant, one is sweet and simple. Sound familiar?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Shelly, I’m so proud of you and Leonard for getting this award.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, thank you, Mother.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: I tried to read your paper, but it was very hard for me to understand.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, it’s quite straightforward, actually. It describes a new model of the universe that conceptualizes it as the surface of an n-dimensional superfluid.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Interesting. You can believe that, but God filling an ark with animals two-by-two is nonsense.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: What did they feed the lions, Mother?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: The floating bodies of drowned sinners, of course.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Listen, Leonard’s mom is a renowned psychiatrist and woman of science. Can you please keep the Bible babble to yourself while she’s here?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Are you ashamed of me?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Of course not. I love you. I’m just embarrassed by the things you believe, do and say.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Well, I love you, too. My little bowl of lion chow.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: So, have you and Penny set a wedding date?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: No, we’re kind of taking it slow.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: I see.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: What does that mean?

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: You’ve been on and off with this woman for seven years and engaged for one year. One has to wonder if there’s a problem. Are you having satisfactory intercourse?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes, Mother.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Only satisfactory. I see.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I change my answer. It, it’s amazing. It’s hot. We can barely keep our hands off each other.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Seems odd to try and impress your mother with your sexual prowess. But then, you always did have that unresolved Oedipal complex.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: See, this right here, what you’re doing, can you please not do that around Sheldon’s mom?

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Why? Are you attracted to her, too?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Of course not. She’s, she’s just a very sweet and God-fearing lady, and you have to be respectful of her beliefs.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Leonard, I’m an adult. I know how to conduct myself around people from different walks of life.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Where is she from again?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: East Texas.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Ugh.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Hey, look who’s here.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, Doctor Hofstadter, it’s so good to see you again.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Likewise. I read your paper, it was very impressive.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, thank you.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: We just spent two hours in traffic. Did you think to mention to me that you liked our paper?

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Of course I did, but it’s a mother’s job to make sure her child’s self-esteem is not dependent on anyone’s approval.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That’s so sweet, you think I have self-esteem.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Doctor Hofstadter, I want you to meet my mother, Mary.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: : So nice to meet you.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Nice to meet you, too. How was your flight?

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Very pleasant. And yours?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Lovely. Almost as if someone, not saying who, was watching over the plane.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: You’re kidding, right?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Subtle, mom, real subtle.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Stuart.

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: Morning.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: We talked about this. I don’t mind you still living here, but we got to have some rules. And rule number one is pants.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Hey.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: You must be very proud of your son.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Oh, yes. He recently argued a case before the Supreme Court.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: He did?

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Oh, you mean this son. Uh, sure, he’s terrific.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Beverly, would you like to see the math I worked out to support our hypothesis?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You mean, my hypothesis. I hypothesized it all by myself.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Calm down, dear. Mary, I’m curious. When did you first realize that your son had such a remarkable mind?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Ooh, good question. Everyone loves stories about Sheldon Cooper, boy genius.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Well, I would have to say when he was 13 and tried to build a nuclear reactor in the tool shed.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Ooh, this is a good one.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Now, the first thing you have to know about Shelly is ever since he was a little boy, he was always concerned with the well-being of others. And he didn’t think that it was fair for people to pay for electricity, so he was gonna power the entire town for free.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Tell her about the uranium. Tell her about the uranium.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, well. Oh, this is adorable. When he arranged to get some yellowcake from Chad, I thought he was talking about Twinkies from one of his friends.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: But I wasn’t. ‘Cause I didn’t have any friends.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: No. It turns out that this little scallywag was trying to use my Visa card to buy uranium from an African warlord in the country of Chad.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Sounds like Sheldon was a handful.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, he was a handful.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I was a handful.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: You still are. Uh, Mom, hey, tell Mary the story about how I made a Van der Graaf generator out of our vacuum cleaner.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: All right. He broke the vacuum cleaner.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: I mean, for a while, everything was vampires. Now it’s all zombies. I wonder what the next monster fad will be.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: We haven’t had a good invisible man in a while.

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: Clearly, you’ve never seen me try to talk to a woman.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Guys. In the time you’ve been sitting here playing video games, I got the car washed, picked up cleaning supplies and went to the bank.

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: I put on pants.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Kiss-ass.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Okay, I don’t know when I became the mother to three lazy teenagers, but it stops today. You guys are cleaning the kitchen, top to bottom.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Hey, I don’t even live here.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Yes or no, do you have clothes in my laundry right now?

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: I do. And some of it’s wool, so dry flat if possible.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, and here’s a picture of me receiving my bachelor of science degree.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: You don’t look very happy.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, I had just begun puberty. It was figuratively and literally one of the hairiest moments of my life.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Shelly does not like change.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, true. But all the clenching in the world will not keep testicles in your abdomen.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey, sorry, got caught up at work. Hi, Beverly.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Hello. Oh, okay.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Sorry, I forgot.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You remember my mother.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, yes. Hi, Mary.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Good to see you again, dear.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Ah, yeah, now that’s what I’m talking about.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: So, Mom, you haven’t seen Penny since we got engaged.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, yeah, let me show you the ring.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Oh, lovely. Must have been very expensive.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, no, not at all. No, we, uh, found a place online that, uh, repurposes diamond drill bits.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: We did not. That’s not true. Can I speak to you alone for a second?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, sure.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: It came from Tiffany’s.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: You mean the box, right?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Keep walking.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Really doesn’t matter to me how much he spent on the ring. I think.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Did I misspeak about the ring?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes, and we’ll get back to that. But, uh, even with your mother here, you are deliberately hogging all the attention from my mom. You’re like one of those elephant seal pups that steals the milk from two mothers.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Do you mean what marine biologists refer to as super weaning?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yes, you are a super weaner.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, now I have to correct you. As a bit of an elephant seal buff, the more accurate comparison would be when two mother seals actively seek to nourish the same pup. So I believe the term you’re looking for is a double mother suckler.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Yeah, you’re right. That is the term I’m looking for. You are a dirty double mother suckler.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Okay, well, now that we have the terminology straightened out. How dare you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: We’re not in a rush. We’ll set a date when the time is right.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: It doesn’t matter, sweetie. The moment a man lays with a woman, they are married in the eyes of the Lord.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Uch.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Uch? The bible is uch to you?

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: No, I’m sorry. That was inappropriate. As a psychiatrist, I know how important people’s superstitions can be to them.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: You want to talk about superstitions? Sheldon sent me the books you wrote, all that nonsense about superegos and ids. What bull dropped that on the barn floor?

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: His name is Sigmund Freud.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Hey, look at that. You both believe in Jewish bearded guys.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Stay out of this.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Mm-hmm.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: At least the bearded man that I believe in preaches love and compassion. All yours talks about is why you hold in your poop and want to crawl back inside your mama.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: It’s fascinating. How can someone as enlightened as Sheldon come from someone like you?

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: I know the answer. You’re not gonna like it.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Try me.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: When I was pregnant with Shelly, I was driving to church, and I was praying to the Lord to give me a son smarter than his dumb-ass daddy. And I looked over and I saw a Jesus bobblehead in the Subaru next to me nodding yes. What is that supposed to mean?

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: : It means, I can’t believe we’re having this conversation.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Well, do it some more. Maybe you can knock some sense into yourself.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Why don’t we all stop hitting ourselves and talk about something safe, you know, like shoes or how cute little Chinese babies are.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: It is not my fault that your mother likes me better than she likes you.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, don’t flatter yourself. She likes everybody better than she likes me.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: How old is this Jell-O?

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: Well, it’s carrots, so gonna say very.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Sorry we have to do this.

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: Bernadette’s not wrong. She does work hard around here.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Yeah, maybe it’s a good thing if she stops babying you so much.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: She doesn’t baby me.

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: I saw her pull you home in a wagon.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: For your information, I twisted my ankle chasing the ice cream truck.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Face it, dude, Bernadette treats you the same way your mother used to, and that was not a healthy relationship.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: You’re right. It’s time for me to act like an adult in this marriage. Starting with my husbandly duty of taking out the trash. Bernie, I made a mess.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: I’m terribly sorry that I upset your mother.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Oh, it’s all right. She’ll forgive you. She has to or she goes to hell.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: I can’t help but notice how her unconditional love for you is diametrically opposed to my own parenting strategies.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Well, you doled out affection as a reward for achievement, a proven way to raise a child. Or train a rat.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: But look how well you turned out.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I’d feign modesty at this point, but who would believe me? Still, you need to consider how successful Leonard’s brother and sister are.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: I suppose.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: While my brother and sister are mouth-breathing idiots.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Do you suppose you would’ve flourished more in a reward-based environment?

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: Perhaps. But my mom made me spaghetti with chopped-up hot dogs whenever I wanted, so who cares?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Not once did my mother ever give me any love or affection for just being myself, I always had to earn it.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Oh, Leonard, I’m sure she loves you very much. In her own cold godless way.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, and you certainly don’t have to earn my love.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Of course, you already knew that when you bought me this princess-cut drill bit.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: That’s not what it is.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: I know, I know. Zzzzzzzz.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: When your mom gets back, I’m gonna need to apologize for the way I spoke to her.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Well, come on now, she did kind of start it.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Doesn’t matter, a good Christian would’ve turned the other cheek. On the other hand, a good Texan would’ve shot her, so, I just kind of split the difference. Hey, who’s in the mood for spaghetti and hot dogs?

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, me.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Yeah, me, too.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: Coming up.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: I don’t really feel I deserve it.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: That was a big sticky mess, but I think I got it.

utterance.speaker: Raj
utterance.content: Looks good.

utterance.speaker: Stuart
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Bernadette
utterance.content: Look at that. You cleaned it up all by yourself.

utterance.speaker: Howard
utterance.content: Yes, I cleaned it up all by myself. Honestly, I don’t know why you complain so… okay, maybe I missed one spot. Just leave.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: I’m so glad that you and I were able to bury the hatchet.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Me, too. And I respect your right to your beliefs.

utterance.speaker: Mrs Cooper
utterance.content: And I will pray for you.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Okay, Mom, let’s get you back to your hotel before anyone says anything else.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: One moment. There’s something I need to say to you.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, really? That’s too bad.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Leonard, I always made you earn my affection, but today I realize that there’s more than one way to raise a child.

utterance.speaker: Sheldon
utterance.content: I taught her that.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Therefore, I would like to initiate a new protocol wherein I shower you with unconditional love.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Wow. When does that start?

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: So needy. Come to Mommy.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: It’s okay, go ahead.

utterance.speaker: Dr Hofstadter
utterance.content: Oh, my son.

utterance.speaker: Leonard
utterance.content: Oh, my mother.

utterance.speaker: Penny
utterance.content: Oh, my God.

utterance.speaker: Stuart (singing)
utterance.content: It’s a hard-knock life.

utterance.speaker: Together (singing)
utterance.content: It’s the hard-knock life for us, it’s the hard-knock life for us. ‘Stead of treated, we get tricked, ‘stead of kisses, we get kicked, it’s the hard-knock life. Got no folks to speak of so it’s the hard-knock row we hoe, cotton blankets ‘stead of wool, empty bellies ‘stead of full, it’s a hard-knock life.
